name: Auberge Les Passants du Sans Soucy

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Our recent stay at Auberge Les Passants du Sans Soucy was entirely enjoyable. This was our first time in Montreal, and being a history buff with a love of architecture, I was very glad i decided to stay on "Old Montreal". MOntreal is certainly a nice mix of old and new; but the quaintness of the old cobblestoned streets, rows of historical buildings and the close proximity most all sites a multitude of restaurants in the area made this choice a good one. We love to walk, take in the sites, blend into the local and that is all quite possible from this B & B.
reviews.title: Quaint & Quiet

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Location is great. Notre Dame within a block, the street this is located on (Rue de St Paul) is the main aveneue through Old montreal packed with great restaurants (from local to fancy to cafe to take-out markets), bars/cafe/pubs abound, and intertwined are boutiques, specialty shops, numerous art galleries, and historical properites - all within blocks in each direction. Also many squares surrounded by such in the area, and it is definitely safe both day and night - very populated. And the waterfront with many museums (in the area) are within blocks in all directions also.
reviews.title: Outstanding
Sans Soucy is "Sans" Problems
reviews.text: Metro (subway) is within a few blocks (up/down a hill) and if you haven't read before - clean, clean, clean (take this from a New York/Bostonian) and frequent (and fast!). Banks in this area also for cash exchange (across from Notre Dame Cathedral).

The B & B itself was once a fur warehouse building - the stone walls are evident throughout, ceiling have wood beams keeping with the original wood beams within the structure supporting walls. We had a room on the second floor of rooms (really third) via the stairway (note - no elevator - just so you know). Honestly, I'm used to historical builidng hotels/B & B etc - but know that some pictures of this B & B (both here and on website) are slightly deceiving of the room size. It is definitely comfortable and adequate for two - but will be smaller than what you see visually. Some rooms may be a bit bigger, but older buildings mean smaller rooms by todays standards if you are not used to it or expect it.
reviews.title: Loved the Auberge

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Cleanliness is top notch. Both upon arrival and throughout our four day stay. Plenty of drawer space for two, and a decent closet with hangers and luggage rack. Gas fireplace was in room and was neat as mood lighting on the rainly nights - I'm sure in the winter it adds to the coziness. No way to control the AC, it's B & B wide - but was comfortable. I especially like to control the fans, and shut them off etc - but it was not big problem during our stay. Bathroom was big (by room standards) with good shower and in our room a very deep jet tub (which we didn't use - so no comment there). Good mirrors and a full length also in the room. Bed was comfortable, small flat screen TV, extra leather chair to lounge in and a desk and chair. Very quaint, antiquish, whire lace window coverings etc....only thing missing was any bath amenities (which is unusual for a B & B - which usually spoil you with good stuff). Just a bar of soap (for the stay) - not shampoo/ lotions etc. was given. Might be a cost saving expense - or found people weren't using? But with the "liquid rules" when flying now - we use what's suppled more than ever for convenience - and like I said, with B&B's it's usually part of the "home" feeling and they usually go over and above the ole Johnson & Johnson special.
reviews.title: fabulous place in Old Montreal!

likes.liked: — the beautiful rooms and the breakfast!

reviews.text: It seems to me I have been searching for the meaning of french culture, and felt the desire to experience the same since I was young. It may have been the charismatic Pierre Trudeau, or perhaps it was the success of the Montreal Canadiens, led by Guy Lafluer and his flowing blonde mane. Something inside me had been inspired a long time ago. Growing up in western Canada, we didn't have access to many things french, nor were we taught to have such foreign asperations. To this day, I cannot say where I developed this craving. I can tell you, however, where my appetite for all that is french has been satisfied. Les Passants du Sans Soucy embraces all that is truely french. Some feel as though they step back in time when they enter Old Montreal, this feeling was taken to another level the first time I stepped into this delightful B&B on the oldest street in the Old Port District. Once inside, the building's mystique had me captured, its history as a warehouse receiving goods from the mighty St. Lawrence took me back to a time when Canada was but an ideal in the minds of men to come. Although now very much in tune with the times, as far as technological advances are concerned, through its elaborate upgrades it has maintained the classic french feel. Each room is unique, with its own sense of style and form, attention to detail is paramount throughout. The same can be said of the staff at LPdSS. Each one with his own perception of the city itself, I feel this gave me an upclose and intimate tour of this truely international gem. I was guided to a number of outstanding restaurants by both Michael and Martin. Each one gauging my mood and intent for their percise suggestions. I do have to say, it is not hard to find a great place close by to spend some time. Whether you're hungry, wanting to indulge in the history that surrounds you, or simply looking for a place to happen, it can be found by wandering the streets adjacent to the hotel. Breakfast is certainly a highlight of one's stay, having a chance to meet others from the corners of the globe. This is a terrific opportunity to find out what the others have been doing during their stay. As many events are seasonal, you may not be aware of all that is happening at once. Upon discovering something of interest, be sure to ask for the pertinent information at the front desk. During my stay, Michael prepared an omlette for me that was again, built to suit my craving at the time. The next morning I tried the french toast, it too had the flavor of a time gone by, metaphorically speaking of course. A classic recipe handed down through the ages I'm sure. Martin made any and all arrangements with ease, making my stay one of the most relaxing and enjoyable getaways to date. I would certainly suggest this destination to anyone planning a trip to the area. For those who haven't been to Montreal, I recommend you consider to travel through time, to a place steeped in french charm and history. It answered many questions formed in the time of my childhood, and leaves me with a special understanding, and a definate appreciation for this wonderful, and truely ecclectic culture. I could not have asked for a better host to my dreams than Les Passants du Sans Soucy.
reviews.title: True French Charm

likes.liked: — Situated in the heart of Old Montreal / The personal touch

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed here for 4 nights and on the last night we stayed in the suite downstairs off the lobby/check-in desk. I did not like the suite as it is right off the busy street and you cannot get any light in from the windows without people walking by and looking in at you. Also, the back door did not open so you could not get any fresh air in this room. In addition, we could hear everything going on in the lobby and felt very uncomfortable that we didn't have much privacy. The room we had for 3 nights was okay, nice enough accomodations but not spectacular. I loved having the windows that you could open and let the fresh air come in.
reviews.title: Okay but didn't LOVE it!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We had such high hopes for this B&B and maybe that was part of the problem. However, the person at the front desk- Michael (not Banks as in the former owner and now owner of Bonaparte) was quite off putting. We felt like we were imposing on the staff especially this Michael anytime we asked a question.
reviews.title: Excellent

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Also, we stayed at Bonaparte as was recommended by Sans Soucy and they made every attempt to assist me with vegetarian breakfast. I simply asked San Soucy for an additional croissant in the morning as I do not eat eggs and was not accomodated one single day! Unbelievable! Each day I was offered EGGS and each day I stated that I don't eat eggs and the owner did not ONE freaking time offer me an additional croissant or anything.
reviews.title: One of the best

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I will say that as off-putting as Michael (not Banks) was at the front desk he was very kind one day and brought me a cup of tea with honey up to my room.
reviews.title: Just the best place to be in Vieux-Montreal

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My wife and I just returned from our one-year wedding anniversary in Montreal. The Auberge Les Passants du Sans Soucy was one of the main reasons why we cancelled the second part of our vacation (a two-day road trip through Vermont) and extended our stay in this terrific city. First of all, the property's location is perfectly situated in the heart of Old Montreal, within walking distance to several great restaurants, sights, and the Place d'Armes metro stop. Second, the rooms (we stayed in room 201 for the first three nights, then the suite for our last night) were spacious, clean, comfortable, charming, and equipped with all the amenities you could possibly want/need (hair dryer, iron and board, televisions, jacuzzi-style bathtubs). Finally, I cannot begin to lavish enough praise upon the staff. Whether it was helping us with our bags, assisting with dinner recommendations and reservations, catering to our requests for extra bath towels, or cooking us delicious omelets for breakfast every morning (included in the room rate!), the staff went above-and-beyond to make our stay a memorable and pleasant one. When my wife and I return to Montreal, we will absolutely stay at Auberge Les Passants du Sans Soucy... and so should you!!!
reviews.title: A wonderful experience!

likes.liked: — The location, comfort, and staff were all superb!!!
likes.disliked: — I liked EVERYTHING about this place!!!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: After reading all the positive reviews of Sans Soucy we were happy to see that they were true. We stayed 3 nights and would have loved to stay longer. After driving up to the hotel we were shown to a parking lot next to the Auberge and checked in at the lobby which looks like a lovely art gallery. The man who greeted us, Michael, had a great sense of humor and charm which made us feel as if we were in a European city. Our room looked just as it did on-line; warm wood, rustic and cozy with a nice, big bathroom. All very clean. What surprised us was how wonderfully quiet the room was at night. The Air conditioning was appreciated. We slept well. The communal breakfast was tasty and generous. We had warm croissants, made-to-order omelets and French toast. We were celebrating a birthday and Michael made us feel like VIPs with excellent recommendations and reserving restaurants for us during our stay in Montreal. The Auberge is in a fantastic location. Since there was a public transportation strike during our stay, we felt lucky to be within walking distance of everything we were interested in. We are looking forward to staying there again.
reviews.title: The great reviews are true

likes.liked: — Restfull sleep in a beautiful location.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: This must be the fifth or sixth time we stayed at this wonderful small hotel. It is one of our favorite places to stay and we always book the same room. Daniel, Martin and Michael Smith are so kind and helpful and make everyone feel at home. They really take care of all requests and also take time to chat. It is like being a guest in someone's home.
reviews.title: Fabulous as Usual
Best place to stay in Montreal
reviews.text: The decor of the rooms is rustic French with exposed stone walls and gleaming polished floors. Beds are very comfortable and the drapes block the light for a restful sleep. The lobby area is a small art gallery and quite interesting and the breakfast room is charming.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The breakfasts themselves are magnificant!!! Possibly the best in Montreal. Fresh orange juice, fresh fruit cup, marvelous home baked croissants--regular and chocolate. Yogurt if desired and a choice of French Toast or omelettes made to order in a wide array of choices. You could eat every day for a week and have a different selection each day. Wonderful bowls of cafe au lait or regular coffee or tea.
reviews.title: Great little B&B

reviews.text: Rooms very comfortable, very clean, good breakfast, staff accomodating, location in old Montreal very good for walking the waterfront, steps from History Museum, and within walking distance to Place des Arts for symphony, theatre, and art museum. Two great restaurants nearby: Restaurant Bonaparte ( directly behind Sans Soucy) and Club Chasee et Peche were both especially memorable.
reviews.title: Good Location

likes.liked: — Location and it was air conditioned

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: This is a fabulous small hotel on the most convenient and interesting street in Vieux Montreal. The breakfast, which is included, was wonderful, served by the owner, Daniel Soucy. The hotel staff was so helpful in giving directions and recommendations on good restaurants.
reviews.title: Great Location and Helpful Staff

likes.liked: — The location, staff and great breakfast

reviews.text: Stayed here for 5 nights in mid September with my college roommate...both celebrating birthdays....we're of a certain age. Because we needed the only room with 2 beds I'd booked this months in advance, based on reading about the Auberge in "1001 places to see before you die". The room was very pleasant, well appointed. Overlooked the Rue St. Paul, which I was somewhat concerned about because of potential street noise, but that turned out to be not a problem. Breakfasts were very good. Advice on where to go and what to see, generally very helpful. The Polish restaurant across the street was a wonderful find....their food was gourmet and gave us a break from the more typical fare found everywhere else. Walking distance to most sights, and simply well located for the evening stroll. I would recommend NOT taking the greyhound bus tour, worst city tour I've taken anywhere ever! Expect an intimate Inn, centrally located, but with the limitations smaller facilities have ...nonetheless, I would stay love to here again were I ever to be back in Montreal.
reviews.title: Well located, very pleasant surroundings

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My wife and I stayed in the suite at Auberge Les Passants du San Soucy in early September 2007. The inn is located in the heart of Old Montreal and gets high marks for being close to fine restaurants and tourist attractions. The staff also get high marks for their knowledge and helpfulness. The suite itself was disappointing. It was sparsely furnitured and the decorations were quite cold. You can't open the blinds as the suite is on the ground floor and you'll put on a peep show through the street level windows. Hence, the suite is either dark or in full public view. The food at the inn was fine. It was neither special nor bad. A better meal could be had at the local patisserie (pastry shop) located two blocks west.
reviews.title: A fine, if not spectacular, choice

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Stay at the Auberge if you want a location inside Old Montreal, but skip the suite and save $60 by booking one of the smaller rooms with windows and blinds you can open.
reviews.title: Charm, comfort and warm hospitality in Old Montreal

likes.liked: — The hospitality, the charm, the breakfasts

aka: Auberge Les Passants Du Sans Soucy Hotel Montreal
